facts.text: In June 1956 there was a strike in the glass factory of the appellant, Ms. Munshi Lal Beni Ram Glass Works, at Ferozabad.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts may first be briefly stated. In June 1956 there was a strike in the glass factory of the appellant, M s. Munshi Lal Beni Ram Glass Works, at Ferozabad. As a result the factory

facts.text: Factory was closed down for some time as a result of the strike.

anchor.surface_text: , at Ferozabad. As a result the factory was closed down for some time. In August 1956 a settlement was reached with the workers

facts.text: In August 1956 a settlement was reached with the workers.

anchor.surface_text: was closed down for some time. In August 1956 a settlement was reached with the workers and it became possible to reassume operations from August 31, 1956.

facts.text: Operations resumed from August 31, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: reached with the workers and it became possible to reassume operations from August 31, 1956. The workers were asked to report personally, latest by August 26, 1956,

facts.text: Workers were asked to report personally by August 26, 1956 to show willingness to work.

facts.text: Lal Khan failed to register his willingness to work before August 26, 1956 according to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: declined, the proceedings before the adjudicator companytinued and on December 31, 1957 the adjudicator gave his award. This was followed by an order

facts.text: State Government enforced award on January 28, 1958 under ss. 3 and 6(2) of U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: his award. This was followed by an order of the State Government dated January 28, 1958 enforcing the award under ss. 3 and 6 2  of the U.P. Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

facts.text: Single Judge allowed writ petition on January 28, 1958 holding no power to enforce award.

anchor.surface_text: A learned Single Judge allowed this later writ petition on January 28, 1958, holding that the State Government had numberpower to enforce the award in question.

facts.text: Division Bench of Allahabad High Court reversed Single Judge on special appeal.

Industrial Disputes Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions Act XXIII of 1957, refers to s.6A as it stood in U.P. Act XXVIII of 1947 prior to its amendment by U.P. Act 1 of 1957 or as it emerged after the said amendment

anchor.surface_text: The short question, the determination of which is decisive of these appeals, is whether s.64 as mentioned in s.16 of the U.P. Industrial Disputes  Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions  Act, 1956  U.P. Act 1 of 1957  as amended by P. Industrial Disputes  Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions  Act XXIII of 1957, refers to s.6A as it stood in P. Act XXVIII of 1947 prior to its amendment by U.P. Act 1 of 1957 or as it emerged after the said amendment.

issues.answer: as it emerged after the said amendment

arguments.claim: Retrospective amendment of s.16 indicates intention to keep alive s.6A as existed prior to U.P. Act 1 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: It was contended on behalf of the appellant that the very fact that the amendment of S. 16 was retrospective so as to date back to April 16, 1957 when S. 16 itself was originally enacted, indicates that s. 6-A as it existed prior to April 16, 1957 was intended to be kept alive.

arguments.claim: Amendment of s.16 prima facie referable to s.6A as it existed at time of amending Act (U.P. Act XXIII of 1957)

anchor.surface_text: Prima facie this amendment in s. 16 made in November, 1957 should be referable to section 6-A in the form in which it existed on the date of the enforcement of the amending Act in question U.P. Act XXIII of 1957 .

arguments.claim: No occasion to specifically provide for old s.6A in s.16 if pending proceedings saved from new Act as old s.6A would apply automatically

anchor.surface_text: Now looking, at the position as it stood on April 16, 1957, it would be seen that s.16 was designed to save the pending proceedings from the operation of U.P. Act No. 1 of 1957 itself. If this Act was held to be inapplicable, then s. 6-A as amended thereby would be excluded and that section as it stood prior to the amendment by U.P. Act No., 1 of 1957 would automatically be attracted.

arguments.claim: Specific incorporation of s.6A in s.16 suggests legislative intention to extend amended s.6A to pending proceedings

anchor.surface_text: To us, however, it seems that to specifically incorporate s.6-A in s.16 in this situation is suggestive of the intention of the Legislature to extend the amended s.6A to the proceedings contemplated by s.16.

anchor.surface_text: We must not be understood to accord our approval to the view of the learned Single Judge that s.6 of the Principal Act having not been repealed simpliciter, but having been replaced by a new section 6 by U.P. Act 1 of 1957, the principle underlying s.6 e  of the General Clauses Act cannot be attracted.

arguments.claim: s.6 General Clauses Act applies to repeal even if followed by fresh legislation unless new Act indicates contrary intention

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this approach is not quite correct. Section 6 would seem to us to apply to a case of repeal even if there is a simultaneous enactment unless a contrary intention appears from the new enactment.

holdings.text: s.16 of U.P. Act 1 of 1957 as amended refers to s.6A as amended by U.P. Act 1 of 1957, not the prior version

anchor.surface_text: To us, however, it seems that to specifically incorporate s.6-A in s.16 in this situation is suggestive of the intention of the Legislature to extend the amended s.6A to the proceedings contemplated by s.16. The enactment under consideration is not an example of ideal draftsmanship and the provisions under consideration may admit of two constructions. Assuming the two constructions to be possible we are not satisfied that the construction placed on this provision by the two Benches of the Allahabad High Court is clearly erroneous justifying reversal of the view taken therein and thereby unsettling the legal position. On the other hand to uphold the view of the learned Single Judge would also render the awards like the present unenforceable, which intention is difficult to impute to the Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reference to s.6A at time of amendment; specific incorporation implies amended version; purposive construction avoids unenforceability; upholds Division Bench over Single Judge

holdings.text: Proceeding pending before adjudicator under s.16 attracts s.6A allowing State Government to enforce the award

anchor.surface_text: In our, opinion the proceeding in question was clearly -pending before the adjudicator as contemplated by s.16. The adjudicator, therefore, could plainly proceed to. adjudicate upon the dispute. On his a judicious the provisions of s.6- A would be attracted and thereunder the State Government could enforce it. This submission of the appellant is, therefore, repelled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.16 contemplates proceedings before adjudicator; adjudication triggers s.6A enforceability by State Government

holdings.text: Resort to s.17 of U.P. Act 1 of 1957 is not essential or a condition precedent for enforcing the award

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, point out that s. 17 only provides for delegated legislation in certain circumstances and resort to s. 17 is number essential, or a condition precedent for enforcing the awards, as suggested on behalf of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17 concerns delegated legislation, not prerequisite for enforcement under s.6A

holdings.text: Decision of adjudicator qualifies as 'award' under s.2(c) when liberally construed for pending proceedings under s.16

anchor.surface_text: Now if U.P. Act No. 1 of 1957 is excluded from its application to pending proceeding under s.16 then the word award has to be liberally construed and so construed it would be covered by s. 6-A. The power conferred by ss. 16 and 6A has to be construed as real and number illusory and it has to be interpreted so as to achieve the purpose for which it was conferred.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liberal construction required to make s.16 and s.6A powers effective and non-illusory

holdings.text: s.6 of General Clauses Act applies to repeal even when followed by fresh legislation on same subject unless contrary intention appears in new Act

anchor.surface_text: We must number be understood to accord our approval to the view of the learned Single Judge that s.6 of the Principal Act having number been repealed simpliciter, but having been replaced by a new section 6 by U.P. Act 1 of 1957, the principle underlying s.6 e  of the General Clauses Act cannot be attracted. In our opinion, this approach is number quite correct. Section 6 would seem to us to apply to a case of repeal even if there is a simultaneous enactment unless a contrary intention appears from the new enactment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects Single Judge; follows Supreme Court precedent in State of Punjab v. Mohar Singh; examines new Act for contrary intention only

holdings.text: s.6 General Clauses Act applicable unless new legislation manifests intention incompatible with its provisions

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court in the State of Punjab v. Mohar Singh 1  whenever there is a repeal of an enactment, the consequences laid down in section 6 of the General Clauses Act will follow unless, as the section itself says, a different intention appears. In the case of a simple repeal there is scarcely any room for expression of a contrary opinion. But when the repeal is followed by fresh legislation on the same subject we would undoubtedly have to look to the provisions of the new Act, but only for the purpose of determining whether they indicate a different intention.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly applies and quotes Supreme Court precedent; broad applicability beyond simple repeal

We cannot therefore subscribe to the broad proposition that section 6 of the General Clauses Act is ruled out whenever there is a repeal-,of an enactment followed by a fresh legislation. anchor.surface_text: To us, however, it seems that to specifically incorporate s.6-A in s.16 in this situation is suggestive of the intention of the Legislature to extend the amended s.6A to the proceedings contemplated by s.16. The enactment under consideration is not an example of ideal draftsmanship and the provisions under consideration may admit of two constructions. Assuming the two constructions to be possible we are not satisfied that the construction placed on this provision by the two Benches of the Allahabad High Court is clearly erroneous justifying reversal of the view taken therein and thereby unsettling the legal position. On the other hand to uphold the view of the learned Single Judge would also render the awards like the present unenforceable, which intention is difficult to impute to the Legislature.
The result is that these appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.
present unenforceable, which intention is difficult to impute to the Legislature. And then this point is number likely to arise very frequently in fut

anchor.surface_text: In our, opinion the proceeding in question was clearly -pending before the adjudicator as contemplated by s.16. The adjudicator, therefore, could plainly proceed to. adjudicate upon the dispute. On his a judicious the provisions of s.6- A would be attracted and thereunder the State Government could enforce it. This submission of the appellant is, therefore, repelled.
The result is that these appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: We may, however, point out that s. 17 only provides for delegated legislation in certain circumstances and resort to s. 17 is number essential, or a condition precedent for enforcing the awards, as suggested on behalf of the appellant.
The result is that these appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

Act No. 1 of 1957 is excluded from its application to pending proceeding under s.16 then the word award has to be liberally construed and so construed it would be covered by s. 6-A. The power conferred by ss. 16 and 6A has to be construed as real and number illusory and it has to be interpreted so as to achieve the purpose for which it was conferred.
The result is that these appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: We must number be understood to accord our approval to the view of the learned Single Judge that s.6 of the Principal Act having number been repealed simpliciter, but having been replaced by a new section 6 by U.P. Act 1 of 1957, the principle underlying s.6 e  of the General Clauses Act cannot be attracted. In our opinion, this approach is number quite correct. Section 6 would seem to us to apply to a case of repeal even if there is a simultaneous enactment unless a contrary intention appears from the new enactment.

anchor.surface_text: As observed by this Court in the State of Punjab v. Mohar Singh 1  whenever there is a repeal of an enactment, the consequences laid down in section 6 of the General Clauses Act will follow unless, as the section itself says, a different intention appears. In the case of a simple repeal there is scarcely any room for expression of a contrary opinion. But when the repeal is followed by fresh legislation on the same subject we would undoubtedly have to look to the provisions of the new Act, but only for the purpose of determining whether they indicate a different intention.
The result is that these appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.
